title: What Does “FRL” Mean? (Plus, When & How to Use It)

steps.title: “FRL” is an abbreviation of “for real.”
steps.content: “FRL” is an abbreviation of “for real.” People use “FRL” to check if someone is being serious, to confirm that what they’re saying is true, or to express agreement with another person. [1] X Research source When it’s used as a question, “FRL?” is another way of saying “seriously?” or “really?” When it’s used as a statement, it means “I’m serious” or “I agree.” The abbreviation can be written in all uppercase (“FRL”) or all lowercase (“frl”). Since “FRL” is a slang term, save it for casual conversations with friends, family members, or your romantic partner. Sometimes, people use “FRL” to mean “for real like,” but it’s less common. Both “for real” and “for real like” have the same meaning.

steps.title: Text “FRL?” to see if someone is being silly or serious.
steps.content: Text “FRL?” to see if someone is being silly or serious. If you can’t tell whether someone is joking online, send a “FRL?” to get to the bottom of things. It conveys shock or disbelief toward what they’re saying, prompting them to respond or share further details. [2] X Research source Them: “Kaitlyn and Parker broke up!” You: “FRL?” Them: “Yes, it happened over winter break.” Them: “I think I’m going to move to Vegas next year.” You: “Frl?” Them: “Nah, I’m just messing with you 😂”

steps.title: Respond with “FRL” to confirm that you’re being truthful.
steps.content: Respond with “FRL” to confirm that you’re being truthful. If someone questions what you’re saying, use “FRL” to tell them you’re serious. It’s a simple response that means you’re not joking around, and you can follow up with more details to confirm you’re telling the truth. [3] X Research source Them: “Really?” You: “FRL, I wouldn’t joke around about this.” Them: “Are you being serious?!” You: “Yeah, it’s frl. I can’t believe it either…😒”

steps.title: Use “FRL” to agree with someone’s statement.
steps.content: Use “FRL” to agree with someone’s statement. If someone expresses an opinion or belief, reply with “FRL” to show you share the same perspective. It’s another way of saying “totally,” “exactly,” or “I agree,” which can make them feel understood and validated. [4] X Research source Them: “Harry looked so hot at the Met Ball 🤤” You: “FRL!!! He always slays ✨” Them: “How is she so positive all the time?” You: “FRL, she needs to share her secrets with the rest of us!”

steps.title: Fräulein
steps.content: Fräulein Sometimes, the abbreviation “FRL” is short for “fräulein,” which is the title of an unmarried German woman. It’s the equivalent to calling someone “Miss” in the United States. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Fire Resistance Level
steps.content: Fire Resistance Level In Australia, the acronym “FRL” may stand for “Fire Resistance Level.” It refers to the ability of a building to withstand a fire for a specific time period, which is determined by structural adequacy, integrity, and insulation. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Forest Reference Level
steps.content: Forest Reference Level The Forest Reference Level (FRL) is part of REDD+, a pact between developing countries to reduce emissions from deforestation and forest degradation. The FRL is a benchmark for activities that reduce emissions and increase removals. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Filter regulator lubricator
steps.content: Filter regulator lubricator An FRL unit in compressed air systems is responsible for delivering clean air at a fixed pressure, and for preventing damage to equipment. It consists of 3 parts: a filter to remove particles, a regulator to control pressure, and a lubricator to provide a controlled amount of oil into the system. [8] X Research source

steps.title: FR Legends
steps.content: FR Legends In the gaming world, the abbreviation “FRL” refers to the car game “FR Legends.” It’s an action-packed mobile game that lets you have drift battles with AI drivers. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Fractional
steps.content: Fractional Less commonly, the abbreviation “FRL” stands for “fractional” in science and mathematics. It’s an adjective that means being related to or expressed as a fraction. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Rly
steps.content: Rly In texting and on social media, “rly” is short for “really.” [11] X Research source People use to emphasize a point or express disbelief about something, especially if they have limited character space in their messages. “Are you rly upset about the situation?” “I’m rly hungry! What type of food are you craving?” “I’m rly not in the mood right now. Please don’t bother me.”

steps.title: Srsly
steps.content: Srsly “Srsly” is the shortened form of the word “seriously,” which is used to emphasize something or ask someone if they’re being honest. [12] X Research source Since it can be tricky to tell whether someone is joking online, “srsly” is one of the best ways to get to the bottom of things. "Do you srsly not want to go anymore?” “You srsly bought those expensive concert tickets?!” “I’m srsly over the whole situation. I’m entering my forgive and forget era 💫”

steps.title: Facts
steps.content: Facts If someone shares a hot take or unpopular opinion, respond with “facts” to convey agreement with them. It’s another way of saying “agreed” or “true,” which typically ends the conversation. [13] X Research source Them: “Lebron is overrated.” You: “Facts.” Them: “Pineapple on pizza is not as bad as everyone thinks.” You: “Facts, that’s actually my favorite topping 🤭”
